title: Spanish
text:
Spanish



I have learned a lot since I started studying Spanish at UCSB in 2022!


In addition to teaching language proficiency, the Spanish major encompasses a diverse range of subjects including linguistics, language and translation, Peninsular Spanish studies, Latin American studies, U.S. Latinx studies, and Indigenous languages and cultures of the Americas.


I had the amazing opportunity to develop my Spanish-speaking abilities while living in Madrid, Spain for a semester.


While in Madrid, I attended the Universidad de Complutense and took classes on Latin American Theater, Modern Spanish Literature, and the Spanish Short Story. Apart from just my studies, I learned a lot about Spanish culture, art, and history through experience.


Take a look at some of my photos from the trip!




¡He aprendido mucho desde que comencé estudiar español en UCSB en 2022!


Además de enseñar la competencia lingüística, la carrera de español abarca una diversa gama de materias que incluyen lingüística, lengua y traducción, estudios de español peninsular, estudios latinoamericanos, estudios Latinx en Estados Unidos, y lenguas y culturas indígenas de las Américas.


Tuve una oportunidad increíble de desarrollar mis habilidades para hablar español mientras vivía en Madrid, España durante un semestre.


Durante mi estancia en Madrid, asistí a la Universidad Complutense y tomé clases de Teatro Latinoamericano, Literatura Española Actual y el Cuento Español. Aparte de mis estudios, aprendí muchas sobre la cultura, arte y historia española a través de experiencias.


¡Echa un vistazo a algunas de las fotos de mi estancia en Madrid!

title: Restoration Ecology
text:
I assist researchers in Carla D’Antonio’s VegLab at UCSB on a project identifying factors influencing vegetation changes in Mediterranean ecosystems. I perform field work measuring plant growth, and soil moisture content, and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR). I also contribute to data inputting and organization of the collected data.













Lake Piru Research Site, June 2024




Photo taken at the research site in Lake Piru, Los Padres National Forest, June 2024.


Photo taken at the research site in Lake Piru, Los Padres National Forest, June 2024.

title: Impact of Wood-boring Beetles on Varietal Oak Woodlands After Fire Events
text:
As the threat of wildfires continues to grow, many are looking towards indigenous knowledge and practices of using fire to maintain the landscape. This can prevent devastating megafires and promote forest health. While prescribed burns offer numerous ecological and cultural benefits, the presence of bark and ambrosia beetles can complicate these outcomes. These insects infest trees by boring beneath the bark, creating spaces to grow and reproduce. In the process, they introduce various fungi into the trees’ sapwood, which can sometimes lead to tree mortality. Since bark and ambrosia beetles tend to target stressed or dying trees, I am investigating whether prescribed burns in infested areas might inadvertently boost beetle populations, potentially increasing tree mortality.
To explore this, I am studying blue oak and coast live oak species following prescribed burns at Sedgwick Reserve, focusing on bark and ambrosia beetle species belonging to Monarthrum and Pseudopityophthorus genera. My approach combines visual surveys and pheromone trapping to quantify changes in beetle populations. This research aims to better understand how these beetles should be managed in fire-prone ecosystems.

title: Impact of Wood-boring Beetles on Varietal Oak Woodlands After Fire Events
text:
Beetle Symptoms
When beetles bore into trees, they create small tunnels called galleries. These galleries affect tree health in several ways: some beetle species lay their larvae inside the galleries and introduce fungi that serve as food for their offspring. Other species use the galleries as shelter while feeding on the tree’s cambium, a vital living layer responsible for transporting nutrients.

title: Impact of Wood-boring Beetles on Varietal Oak Woodlands After Fire Events
text:
Beetle Photos
These are unidentified bark/ambrosia beetles that I collected from an ethanol-baited pheromone trap at Sedgwick Reserve on July 25, 2025
I have also uploaded a full inventory of the beetles I collected from these traps over the summer here.

title: Impact of Wood-boring Beetles on Varietal Oak Woodlands After Fire Events
text:
Preliminary Findings and Acknowledgments
I would like to sincerely acknowledge my advisor, Dr. Shane Dewees, for encouraging me to pursue this project and for his consistent guidance throughout. I also thank Dr. Frank Davis, Dr. Leander Love-Anderegg, and the LEAF Lab for their valuable support.
I received support and funding for this project from the University of California Natural Reserve System Field Science Fellowship and UCSB’s Undergraduate Research & Creative Activities Grant. Here is my first midway report for the UCNRS and my preliminary findings that I presented at URCA Week Poster Colloquium:






Bark Beetle entry holes, galleries, and fungus in a blue oak. Sedgwick Reserve, Dec 2024.


Bark beetle entry holes + fungal staining on a coast live oak. Sedgwick Reserve, Dec 2024.

title: Research
text:
I am a research assistant at UCSB, working in both the Anderegg Landscape Ecophysiology and Function (LEAF) Lab and Carla D’Antonio’s Vegetation Lab. The projects I am currently involved in focus on quantifying the physiological effects of prescribed fire on oak trees and identifying potential drivers of vegetation change in Mediterranean ecosystems. In addition to this work, I am conducting a personal research project examining the impact of bark beetles on oak woodlands after fire events.














Impact of Wood-boring Beetles on Varietal Oak Woodlands After Fire Events



Personal Projects



Bark beetles and other woodborers significantly influence forest health, and a deeper understanding of their relationship with fire is essential for developing safe and…


















Physiological Effects of Prescribed Fire on Oak Trees

title: Costume Design
text: Over the course of a quarter at UCSB, I collaborated with a design team to create costumes for two dance pieces in UCSB’s 2025 Spring Dance Concert: Afterlight. I worked closesly with the lighting designer and choreographer of each piece to make their visions become a reality.

title: Costume Design
text:
Piece 1

We Were Light
Design Statement:
This dance was a whimsical piece centered around nostalgia toward one’s childhood and how relationships progress overtime. With themes of realness, rawness, and humanity, this piece honored the dancers not only as performers, but as individual artists with their own stories to tell.
I designed large, billowing skirts that accentuate the playfulness on the choerography. The costumes are primarily white to symbolize innocence and youth, however, each of the seven dancers had a unique color accent on their top and on the bottom-most layer of their skirt. As each dancer moved across the stage, their skirts moved with them, flashing a fun pop of color and personailty. When the dancers stood together, it formed a color pattern reminiscent of a golden sunset palate, reflecting the sun setting on their childhood and the transition into adulthood and independance.

title: Costume Design
text:
Piece 2

the point being
design statement: we were never strangers. its undoing, its endurable. unwrap what you have done and we shall not flinch. this is the ache of being alive and beautiful. this is the unfair proximity to a dream.
the costumes in this piece were designed to flow with one another in form, creating one fluid piece as the dancers interacted. this reflects how humans are ultimately all the same on the inside, bound together by emotion. in sharing and confronting this raw, aching emotion, we are able to connect with one another. the sheerness of the fabric symmbolizes the vulnerability that accompanies what it means to love and be loved, while red thread wraps around the dancer’s torso, wrists, and ankles to represent the blood and pain that it requires to be truly known.












































Final rendering of costume design for We Were Light


Final rendering of costume design for The Point Being


Draping process for the point being costumes


Draping process for the point being costumes

title: Sustainable Swimwear
text:
I designed and crafted two styles of slow-fashion, athletic swimwear: a one-piece swimsuit and a two piece bikini. Both items are reversible (brown and black), seamless, and extremely comfortable. I designed the items to be long-lasting, which I feel is one of the most important qualities for sustainable clothing.

title: Brooke P. Ryan
text:
About Me
Hi there! My name is Brooke and I am from Pittsburgh, Pa. I moved to California in 2021 to attend the University of California, Santa Barbara, where I recently completed my studies. This site is a portfolio of my professional and academic experince, as well as an outlet to show off my personal interests like entomology and sewing/design. Thanks for visiting, I hope you enjoy!

title: Brooke P. Ryan
text:
Currently
I graduated from UCSB with a double major in Environmnetal Studies & Spanish in the spring of 2025. I am now working as a lab technician with Lee Anderegg’s Landscape Ecophysiology and Function (LEAF) Lab and investigating a personal research project on wood-boring beetles and their relationship with fire events. I plan to continue my career in research by getting my PhD in Entomology or Invertebrate Ecology!

title: About Me
text:
Background
Originally from Pittsburgh, Pa, I came to UCSB in 2021 to pursue a degree in Environmental Studies. Since then, I developed an interest in Spanish language, literature, and history which led me to pursue a second degree in Spanish.

title: Physiological Effects of Prescribed Fire on Oak Trees
text:
Sedgwick Reserve, July 2024
I work with Dr. Lee Anderegg’s Landscape Ecophysiology lab on a project quantifying the Physiological Effects of Prescribed Fire on Oak Trees. This research takes place at Sedgwick Reserve, where I assist in collecting branch samples and measuring leaf and stem conductance, minimum stomatal conductance, and thermal vulnerability curves. Additionally, I help input, organize, and analyze the data collected during the research.




Collecting branches from post-burn trees to measure leaf and stem hydraulic conductivity. Sedgwick Reserve, July 2024

title: Insecta
text:
Insecta is the largest class in the entire animal kingdom, with approximately 30 recognized orders and nearly 1 million described species. Scientists estimate there may be as many as 10 million insect species on Earth.
Take a look at a few that have caught my eye recently:
Click on the images for tags and identifications!

title: Arachnida
text: I know many people don’t share my love for spiders, scorpions, and their eight-legged kin—and for good reason. Arachnids aren’t just eerie to look at; some have incredibly potent venom and deliver painfully memorable bites. But I’ve found that the more I learned about them, the less afraid I felt and the more fascinated I became. To me, arachnids are among the most advanced and intriguing creatures on Earth. That’s why I’ve added a “Fun Facts” section to kick off this page—so even those with arachnophobia might come to appreciate their so-called enemies just a little more.

title: Arachnida
section: Araneae (Tarantulas, Jumping Spiders, Orbweavers, Widows, etc)
